Acceptance Criterion: An introduction to how the app works is displayed the first time the app is launched.
The introduction to how the app works is not displayed when the app is launched subsequently.
The explanatory content is available to app users in the respective functional areas.
By using the app, the user accepts the terms of use and privacy provisions.
The terms of use can be displayed within the app.
The consent prompt is shown only the first time a user launches the app.
Confirmation of the creation of pseudonymized IDs and their transmission to nearby devices by the app is a prerequisite for using the app.
The prompt no longer appears after the first time the app is used.
The authorization to use the generation of pseudonymous IDs and send them to nearby devices is already contained in the usage of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE).
The configuration of the general Bluetooth functions is only possible in the system settings.
The app's notification settings are queried before the app is used for the first time.
This enables local notifications.
True push notifications from external servers are not supported (APNs/FCM).
The prompt no longer appears after the first time the app is used.
The configured system language is detected.
If the content is not available in the detected system language, English is selected by default.
The first version of the app is expected to be available also in languages other than English.
Accessibility is provided depending on the options available in the respective operating system.
The app will either contain a link to a web page with FAQs, which is displayed in a browser window, or the web page will be displayed within the app itself.
An explanation of the app's various functions will be provided.
An explanation of the app's various functions will be provided.
There is a “Publication information” item in the menu.
The publication information contains the usual information required.
The app provides simple access to the terms of use and data privacy information.
The app offers access to a technical hotline and a hotline for obtaining a phone TAN.
The times the hotline is available (such as 24/7) is displayed.
Phone numbers can be called directly from the app.
The functions for generating pseudonymized IDs and sending them to nearby devices can be activated and deactivated.
The consequences of activation/deactivation are explained.
The app can be reset to the delivery defaults with a setting option.
The saved traces have to be deleted through the system settings.
App users can call a menu for app settings.
Notifications can be activated and deactivated.
Access to the functions for generating pseudonymized IDs and sending them to nearby devices can be activated and deactivated.
Before access permissions are deactivated, I receive information as to which app functions will no longer work.
Depending on the notification settings, the app sends a notification to the user.
If the risk assessment for a user changes, a notification informs users that there is news in the app.
The actual changed risk assessment is not displayed until the app is opened.
A notification leads the user to the app.
The recommendations from the RKI are defined statically in the app.
Only positive tests can trigger a warning.
This is ensured by the verification server and the hotline for the phone TAN procedure.
A warning can only be triggered once for each test.
A notification merely informs you that there is news in the app.
The test result itself can only be seen in the app.
An info text with defined content is displayed in the app (for example, information about the outcome of the test result, information about necessary measures, a hotline number).
A QR code provided on a flyer from the medical professional or test center can be scanned with the Corona-Warn-App.
An explanatory text is displayed.
A notification merely informs you that there is news in the app.
The test result itself can only be seen in the app.
The notification does not explicitly indicate whether the result is positive or negative.
The IDs can be sent to the Warn server pseudonymized.
Data transmission is only possible if successfully verified beforehand.
This is ensured by the verification server and the hotline for the phone TAN procedure.
Data transmission is only possible if the app user has granted consent beforehand.
The center responsible can generate a TAN and provide it to the person.
The TAN is generated by a server, not the call center itself.
It is possible to enter a TAN within the app.
The app verifies the entered TAN and provides feedback as to whether it was correct.
The IDs can be sent to the Warn server pseudonymized.
Data transmission is only possible if successfully verified beforehand.
This is ensured by the verification server and the hotline for the phone TAN procedure.
Data transmission is only possible if the person has granted consent beforehand.
Thresholds can be configured dependent on the provided API.
The app receives dynamic configurations from the RKI that can affect how the risk assessment is calculated.
The phone number of the technical hotline is available in the app.
Accessibility regarding audio output is provided depending on the options available in the respective operating system.
Accessibility regarding contrast and font size/type is provided depending on the options available in the respective operating system.
The texts and languages are defined by the ordering party.
Content management will be carried out based on RKI requirements.
Content will be differentiated by static and dynamic content, in line with technical feasibility.
In the initial version, updates will be performed through an app update.
